S4.T1.caption: TABLE I: Comparison of Test Performance with Various Similarity Metrics
S4.T1.table:
Method Fang-Med Fang-mKrum Targeted
IID NIID IID NIID IID NIID
Kernel CKA 69.20 38.46 70.22 43.24 71.44/6e-07 52.09/0
Linear CKA 10.00 13.13 64.09 39.55 71.02/0.0007 49.53/0.0616
MMD 63.39 40.90 69.69 32.27 70.85/1e-09 50.51/9e-05
Cosine 68.82 33.90 68.81 10.04 69.76/0.0002 59.87/0.0001
Euclidean 69.06 27.82 68.54 41.57 69.17/0.0221 55.55/0.1354
references: FedCC aggregates non-scaled selected weights where the selection is based on the measurement of the CKA similarities between global and local models‚Äô PLRs. As described in Algorithm

lines 2 to 5, a server first extracts PLRs of the global and local model and measures the kernel CKA between the global PLR and each local PLR (lines 7-9). We chose to compare only PLRs (i.e., not all layers) because it is the most differentiable layer among differently trained models. Also, we chose to use RBF CKA because the similarity differences between non-IID clients are smaller than the non-IID and malicious clients. The similarity values are further clustered using a simple K-means clustering algorithm, where the number of clusters is two: benign and malicious (line 11). Any clustering method can be used as long as it can produce only two clusters.
Regarding the assumption that the number of attackers is less than

, we set the clients in the cluster having a less number as suspects (lines 13-18). We assign the index of suspicious clients in suspects (line 19) and then only average the clients‚Äô weights not belong to the suspects (lines 21-31) ‚Äî excluding the suspicious clients‚Äô weights from aggregation. Because weight scaling could prevent the model from convergence even when it reaches optima, we do not scale any weights whether they are classified as benign. We termed our proposed method as FedCC.

Different from Krum and Bulyan, which requires the number of attackers as inputs, and FLARE, which allows the server to have raw data, our proposed method requires neither any knowledge about the clients nor any instance of data, thus taking full advantage of FL in the perspective of privacy preservation. Furthermore, FedCC is effective in a practical situation; FedCC distinguishes malicious from benign clients even when the benign ones have non-IID data.

As mentioned above, the server cannot access local datasets; it instead receives the trained model parameters (weight in this case) of selected clients. Thus, the only way to determine whether a client has malicious intent is to analyze the weights it received. The output of the last layer before the softmax layer takes the end result of the convolution and pooling process and reaches a classification decision. In other words, computed weights of the second last layer contain the essential and indicative information that affects the classification result the most.

To prove that PLR is the most distinguishable layer out of all layers, we measure the distance between two clusters of clients, namely benign and malicious, using dendrograms with a single linkage metric and correlation distance method. The cluster distances of all layers are illustrated in

. Each line refers to the cluster distances under attack in IID or non-IID settings; for example, the line ‚Äômkrum_iid‚Äô illustrates the cluster distance under the untargeted-mKrum attack in an IID setting. Observably, the cluster distance is the largest in PLR among all layers; it means that the degree of differences is the maximum with PLRs. We thus decided to use the weights of the penultimate layer of local models, which contains the most characteristic, refined, and rich-enough information among any other layers, to compare its similarity to the global model.

, or CKA, is a similarity metric to measure how similar or different two neural networks are from each other. It compares representations between layers or differently trained models. It creates similarity kernel matrices in the individual space and compares the similarity matrices to characterize the representation space. It has multiple outstanding abilities; it can learn similarities between layers of different widths, random initialization, invertible linear transformations, orthogonal transformations, and isotropic scaling. In other words, given two trained networks with the same architecture but different initialization, layers at the same depth should be most similar to each other.

summarized the test performance with the CIFAR10 dataset under two untargeted attacks and one targeted attack, separably in IID and Non-IID settings. We compared the test accuracy when applying Kernel CKA, linear CKA, MMD, Cosine similarity, and Euclidean similarity. The values under the column ‚Äôtargeted‚Äô are the combination of the test accuracy and backdoor confidence, where the high test accuracy and low backdoor confidence mean the best performance. We can observe that Kernel CKA resulted in the highest accuracy on multiple experiments; thus, we decided to use kernel CKA to compare the similarities of PLRs.

We cannot explicitly assume the data are whether IID across multiple clients. If the data clients have is non-IID, it could be possible to have large angular or magnitude differences, even if they are benign. We thus want a similarity metric that does not depend on distance, and direction (angle), so we use kernel CKA to measure the similarity between the global model‚Äôs PLR and the local models‚Äô PLRs.

S6.T5.table:
Untargeted-Krum (Non-IID)
Dataset FedAvg Krum Coomed Bulyan FLARE FedCC
fMNIST 64.63 16.51 57.12 13.39 49.54 66.27
CIFAR10 33.69 15.38 35.70 19.23 17.03 37.40
CIFAR100 2.27 1.00 4.85 0.98 7.46 14.51
Untargeted-Med (Non-IID)
Dataset FedAvg Krum Coomed Bulyan FLARE FedCC
fMNIST 16.32 49.33 68.90 64.12 52.25 72.76
CIFAR10 10.02 25.06 40.23 32.47 14.59 42.37
CIFAR100 1.00 6.24 10.27 6.91 1.00 16.12
references:
shows the test accuracy of the global model on three datasets (fMNIST, CIFAR10, and CIFAR100) under Untargeted-Krum and Untargeted-Med in a non-IID environment.
Interestingly, the robust aggregation algorithms often result in lower accuracy than when the server only takes an average (i.e., FedAvg). This is because of inaccurate filtering of malicious clients; for example, indeed malicious clients are wrongly marked as benign, so their weights are aggregated. In the upper section (i.e., Untargeted-Krum), we can observe that the accuracy has dropped by a large margin when applying Krum and Bulyan. This is obvious as Untargeted-Krum is explicitly designed to degrade the accuracy when Krum is applied. Coomed cannot effectively mitigate this attack because median values of the weights often fail to represent benign clients, especially in non-IID settings. We also presume the relatively low accuracy of FLARE is because it scales weights even when the model is already showing good performance. Instead, FedCC selectively averages weights, neither boosting nor minimizing. FedCC significantly outperforms the other methods in the experiments with CIFAR100. Some methods like Coomed and FLARE result in better test accuracy meaning somewhat mitigation against the attack; however, as shown, the accuracy is almost twice higher with FedCC. FedCC shows the highest accuracy (66.27% for fMNSIT, 37.40% for CIFAR10, and 14.51% for CIFAR100).

The lower section (i.e., Untargeted-Med) is a different story. The accuracy of FedAvg dropped by a large margin because this attack makes the median values deviate from the direction if there is no attack, making outliers. It also explains the relatively high accuracy when Coomed and Bulyan are applied ‚Äì coordinate-wise median and trimmed mean ignore the outliers. However, FLARE shows a similar trend to the above attack due to the weight scaling. Commonly for both attacks, we can observe that Krum is less robust than Coomed, and Bulyan is less robust than Coomed. It is because Krum picks one local model as the global model, but Coomed aggregates multiple local models to update the global model. Also, Bulyan takes averages of multiple chosen clients, thus having more probability of the malicious model being selected, especially when the benign clients have non-IID data.

FedCC outperforms the other methods showing the highest accuracy (72.76%, 42.37%, and 16.12%, for fMNIST, CIFAR10, and CIFAR100, respectively), even though it does not share any raw data with the server or the other clients. We assume FedCC mitigates both attacks the best because 1) PLRs have the essence of refined information, and 2) the CKA similarity is high for those between the benign clients having non-IID data shard than between the benign and malicious clients.

S6.T6.table:
Targeted (Non-IID)
Dataset FedAvg Krum Coomed Bulyan FLARE FedCC
fMNIST 79.07 43.46 71.25 73.58 60.57 84.54

references: summarizes the test accuracy, under targeted backdoor attacks in a non-IID setting. We also plot the confidence of the backdoor task in Figure
to show how well we minimize the confidence of the backdoor task. We also include the results of baselines.

, Krum, choosing one client‚Äôs weights as a global model, is less robust than the other methods aggregating multiple clients‚Äô weights. Coomed and Bulyan, which employ coordinate-wise median and trimmed mean with multi-Krum, respectively, result in relatively higher test accuracy. FLARE lower the main test accuracy due to weight scaling, similar to the trend in Untargeted attacks. Nevertheless, FedCC shows the highest test accuracy, indicating that filtering malicious clients via CKA similarity comparison is more accurate than relying on first-order statistical methods, such as mean or median.

Also, not to lose generality, we take averages of the results from three experiments in the same setting.
As shown in Figure

, FedCC nullifies the backdoor confidence the most. We assume it is the advantage of leveraging CKA, which can calculate the similarity value even when the models are trained on different datasets (different data distribution, in this case) and were initialized differently.

It is true that the other baselines, such as Bulyan, also reduce confidence; however, we argue that FedCC preserves or recovers the test accuracy the most due to the precise discrimination of malicious clients. Also, the steady low confidence indicates that FedCC does not depend on the number of samples or how data are distributed across clients.

S6.T7.caption: TABLE VII: Test Accuracy in an Untargeted-Krum and Untargeted-Med Attack in an IID Setting
S6.T7.table:
Untargeted-Krum (IID)
Dataset FedAvg Krum Coomed Bulyan FLARE FedCC
fMNIST 75.55 31.66 87.62 50.30 79.16 89.23
CIFAR10 49.67 40.86 57.40 12.67 25.77 67.12
CIFAR100 13.72 1.04 6.17 1.59 7.49 18.47
Untargeted-Med (IID)
Dataset FedAvg Krum Coomed Bulyan FLARE FedCC
fMNIST 20.86 85.33 86.70 87.45 71.08 88.44
CIFAR10 9.51 54.28 59.20 57.69 49.82 64.74

references: Table¬†VII shows the test accuracy of the global model on three datasets under untargeted attacks in IID settings. The trends seem similar to that of non-IID experiments, but the test accuracy values are a bit higher as the clients have IID data. In the upper section of the table (i.e., Untargeted Krum), Krum and Bulyan result in relatively low accuracy because the attack explicitly targets to interrupt Krum and its variety. When applying Coomed, the accuracy is increased by a large margin because the median values can represent benign clients when every client has an evenly distributed data shard. FLARE could not continuously guarantee well-recovered accuracy because weight scaling constantly changes the weight even if the model is optimized to the minimum. Since FedCC does not scale weights, the model is solely optimized to the minimum by averaging the selected clients. It thus results in the highest accuracy (89.23% for fMNIST, 67.12% for CIFAR10, and 14.51% for CIFAR100).

S6.T8.caption: TABLE VIII: Test Accuracy in a Backdoor Attack in IID Setting
S6.T8.table:
Targeted (IID)
Dataset FedAvg Krum Coomed Bulyan FLARE FedCC
fMNIST 89.32 85.52 88.45 89.35 67.65 90.16
CIFAR10 52.20 45.37 49.27 55.77 10.09 51.57
CIFAR100 12.73 8.37 15.91 16.59 1.71 18.08
references:
are test accuracy and backdoor confidence against the targeted backdoor attack in an IID setting, respectively. Nine benign clients and one malicious client participate in the training process, and all their weights are sent to the server for aggregation. Since targeted backdoor attacks stealthily train the global model to misclassify an attacker-chosen class to an attacker-chosen label while the remaining classes are classified normally, test accuracy has not been significantly dropped for all datasets. However, we can observe that the confidence, the likelihood of being misclassified, has been reduced to almost zero with FedCC, invalidating the backdoor task. The confidence of attack of FedCC is much lower than those of FedAvg and Bulyan, which showed better test accuracy for the CIFAR10 dataset. Maintaining the test accuracy is important, but if the defense method cannot considerably reduce the attack confidence, it is difficult to say that the attack is effectively mitigated.
Thus, we could conclude that our proposed method does reach the highest test accuracy on the fMNIST and CIFAR100 datasets and comparable accuracy on the CIFAR10 dataset while nullifying the backdoor confidence for all datasets.

references: We analyze the impact of the total number of clients, 100, 60, and 40, where the participation fraction and the proportion of malicious clients are fixed as 0.1 and 0.3. In other words, we set the numbers of malicious clients to 3, 2, and 1, where the numbers of clients being aggregated are 10, 6, and 4, respectively. The test accuracy is summarized in

. The accuracy goes down as the total number of clients gets smaller. This is because of the data heterogeneity. The weights of only four clients are aggregated when there are 40 clients in total, meaning the learned global model is trained on less diverse data or biased. Nonetheless, FedCC achieves the highest accuracy in almost every case. It indicates that the similarity comparison method (i.e., CKA) correctly filters the malicious clients, even if the clients have non-IID data shards, without sharing any data or knowledge with the server.

references: In this section, we examine the impact of the participating fraction of clients where the number of total clients is fixed. The participating fractions of clients are 0.1, 0.3, and 0.5, such that the numbers of clients being aggregated are 10, 30, and 50, respectively. The proportion of malicious clients is fixed at 0.3, such that the malicious clients are 3, 9, and 15, respectively. The test accuracy under untargeted attacks is summarized in

. We can observe that the test accuracy tends to increase as the participation fraction is greater under untargeted-Krum attacks. It implies that the more client participation in a non-IID setting, the more accurate the global model is produced if the attacks are effectively mitigated. Under untargeted-Med attacks, the test accuracy is the highest with FedCC and second highest with Coomed. These indicate that selectively choosing clients based on CKA similarity is more reliable than taking the median value of each coordinate in a non-IID setting.

Throughout the experiment, the global model trained with FLARE did not converge, and the test accuracy fluctuated. The fluctuation is due to the weight scaling while randomly selecting clients. Unlike previous experiments, the server chooses a fraction of the client every round, meaning not-yet-trained models can be selected. In this environment, weight scaling leveraged by FLARE constantly improperly scale the local weights, causing divergence and fluctuation.

references: To examine the impact of the number of local epochs, we doubled up the number of local epochs such that the local models are trained for six epochs in benign clients and twelve epochs in malicious clients. The test accuracy is summarized in
, and the confidence of backdoor task is illustrated in

.
We observe that doubling the number of local epochs brings the convergence of the confidence of backdoor attacks forward while better at maintaining test accuracy (i.e., compared to

), but it also solidifies the impact of the robust aggregation. It is true that Coomed and FLARE significantly reduce the backdoor confidence as well as FedCC; however, the test accuracy has even increased with FedCC due to its precise discrimination of malicious clients.
